Story:
I glanced at the clock on my phone, heart pounding. The team meeting was starting in five minutes, and I was supposed to be there—virtually, at least. My manager had stressed how today’s updates were crucial, and missing them meant being out of the loop for the rest of the project. I could already imagine the disappointed looks from my colleagues, the subtle shift in trust if I didn’t show up or contribute.

But as I settled into the operator’s seat, the cabin door slid open. The transit authority supervisor stepped in, clipboard in hand, eyes sharp. “Unannounced audit,” he said, voice clipped. My training kicked in: focus, precision, no distractions. Every action, every announcement, every stop had to be flawless. There was no room for error, no time to glance at my phone or sneak in a comment on the meeting chat.

I felt the pressure mounting from both sides—my team expecting my presence and input, the supervisor expecting unwavering professionalism. My mind raced, torn between the demands of my colleagues and the immediate scrutiny of my job. I gripped the controls, caught in the impossible space between two worlds, unsure which expectation I could afford to let down.
